I have created a dummy plugin that contributes a launch configuration. The launch configuration has its own source lookup director and sourcepath computer. Its source path computer makes use of the Java Source Path computer to create the defaults.

Bug.Summery: Proposal: Add a "runtime-only" tag to all.maps file in order to improve efficiency of packager tool
Bug.WithStack:
Currently, there are two tags available as content filters for the packager tool, runtime and sdk. However, some features(CDT, for example) are available as runtime only. Therefore, in order to build a package containing all features, one must specify "contentFilter=runtime, sdk". This necessitates downloading all runtime and sdk packages, even when the runtime zips are redundant.
A solution is to add a runtime-only tag to the configs in the all.maps file. runtime-only would be used in addition to runtime in packages that do not have a corresponding sdk. CDT would be "|runtime, runtime-only|" for example. This would allow users to set their contentFilter variable to "sdk, runtime-only" in order to avoid downloading extraneous files. This is a decision of the IES team. CC'ing Jeff for comment. The list of tags has never been limited but I believe it should be a decision that should be taken with the leaders of IES.

Bug.Summery: NPE manipulating a manifest file for a non-plugin project

Lines.Line: - version (Overview tab) - keeps disappearing when I leave the field or press
- adding an extension causes a NPE
- adding an extension point causes a NPE

Bug.WithStack:
I created a simple project and added a META-INF folder. When I added a MANIFEST.MF file (no plugin.xml so far), a PDE editor opened... I thought: "cool!".
To my surprise, I could edit many fields in the JAR manifest using the GUI PDE provides, except: - version (Overview tab) - keeps disappearing when I leave the field or press <enter> - adding an extension causes a NPE - adding an extension point causes a NPE
Although it would be great if a plugin.xml were automatically created for me when I saved the MANIFEST.MF using PDE's editor, I would not go that far (not for 3.0). I have a problem with the NPEs though. The actions should not be enabled, or a message should be presented to the user if it does not make sense in the current context. Of course, Rafael is the first one to stumble upon this one. Creating a plugin.xml on the fly is the only missing link remaining.. I got there by accident... I was actually testing our code, creating a bogus manifest file manually in the text edtor, but was (gladly) surprised to get PDE's editor instead. Couldn't resist playing a little bit with it... We have the code in RC2 that does most of the work required here, but there is an issue with creating a new extension from a template. We used to make a call to ensure that plugin.xml is created (and the required changed made in the editor) when 'finish' is pressed in the new extension wizard. However, when we enter the template wizard, it takes over and its 'finish' is called first.
The proposed fix is to override WizardDialog and make a call to ensure manifest is created in 'okPressed'. This works well in both cases because the file is created prior to any wizard using it.
This is important enough to be included in RC3. Wassim? Created attachment 12186 Patch for fixing the template NPE when manifest file is missing The attached patch also addresses the problem that the newly created plugin.xml did not have schema version == 3.0. Bug.Summery: XYLayoutEditPolicy always erases on deactivate
Bug.WithStack:
deactivate should only call eraseSizeOnDropFeedback if that feedback is actually being shown. Look for similar approaches in other editpolicies.
Also, the use of null will be unexpected in clients. I'm not sure what to do about that. The convention (NonResizableEditPolicy, GraphicalNodeEditPolicy) seems to be to hold onto the feedback figure, and in deactivate call removeFeedback() after a null check. This is essentially what the erase... method does as well. So, in this case we could do the same thing (the feedback is held onto in LayoutEditPolicy, so we'd move the deactivate check to there). This also avoids the problem regarding a bogus or null request.

Bug.Summery: [Misc] All outgoing changes WorkingSet or Filter

Lines.Line: 1. Create a synchronization for your entire workspace and switch it to outgoing
2. The synchronize view shows error/warning markers now so you can see if you

Bug.WithStack:
Once I have some feature started that I am working on, it would be great to be able to navigate around and see only the changed files which I am working on. How about a working set which contains all outgoing resources?
This could also be a filter on top of whatever working set is currently selected. That way I could quickly toggle it, and it could be used in conjunction with other working sets. Or, it could be a working set which is a sub-type of the resource working set.
Another type of unrelated mix-in which might be useful would be anything with a compile error. That way, if you touch a file and introduce a compile error, you could see both the outgoing change and the problems it would cause if released. How about the following: 1. Create a synchronization for your entire workspace and switch it to outgoing mode. 2. The synchronize view shows error/warning markers now so you can see if you are releasing compile errors.
But as far as using the existing working set mechanism to filter the packages/navigator view, that would be more involved. One problem with filtering existing views is that they don't support non-existing resources. We won't be able to show outgoing deletions. I don't want to see outgoing deletions. I just want to see what I am currently working on (and any problems, in the case of errors), and outgoing changes is a rough approximation of this. Using the synchronize view is similar, but it's not quite the same. I agree that this feature would be useful but this is not the intended use of working sets. To use working sets for this would be clunky at best (i.e. working sets are not intended to be dynamic). Therefore, it would be better as a filter. Unfortunately, at the current time, their is no mechanism for defining general filters that apply to all views. To do this, we would need a mechanism similar to the popupMenu objectContribution for registering filters with the workbench. This may have been included as part of the generic resource navigaotr work. We should investigate post 3.0. I have created a Package Explorer filter which does exactly what I want. It works great. In addition to outgoing changes, the filter also shows anything with Errors in it (so that you know if your changes affected other classes). The main problem is that this is a single "filter" which must recognize both compiler errors and outgoing changes. You cannot create two filters and combine them additively.
Also, workbench does not expect Filters to dynamically change, so there is no dispose() method on filter. I hooked the Control's dispose event to remove listeners added by the filter. Also, the filter doesn't know when it becomes disabled, so when any events are received it has to first check to see if it is enabled, and if not remove its listeners.
Filters are a "glass half empty" approach. We need the opposite which I would call "providers". I'm using "provider" as a UI term and not an implmentation term such as Label/ContentProvider. When the packages view is populated, it would start with nothing, and allow providers to additively decide what should be viewed, and for filters to then decide what should get screened. Then, I would enable the following providers separately:
1) Outoing CVS changes 2) Compile Errors 3) Unshared projects/resource (local stuff).
